Facebook Twitter LinkedIn Threads Email 0 Open and scroll to the comments section On Friday, the Supreme Court ruled on three cases challenging President Donald Trump’s massive system of tariffs imposed under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act of 1977 (IEEPA). In a 6-3 decision , the court rightly held that IEEPA does not give the president the power to impose tariffs. Among the cases decided was VOS Selections Inc. v. Trump , which the Liberty Justice Center and I filed on behalf of five small American businesses harmed by the tariffs (we were later joined by prominent litigators Neal Katyal and Michael McConnell). The decision is important for its impact on tariffs, and as a rejection of a sweeping executive power grab. But it also raises a crucial broader—and as yet unresolved—issue: how much deference to give presidential invocations of sweeping emergency powers. That issue is central to various cases working their way through the courts, and may soon arise again in the tariff context. Trump’s April 2025 “Liberation Day” executive order invoked IEEPA to impose 10 percent tariffs on almost every nation in the world, plus large additional “reciprocal” tariffs against dozens of other countries. He also used IEEPA to impose 25 percent tariffs against Canada and Mexico, and 10 percent tariffs against China, supposedly justified by the flow of fentanyl into the United States from those countries. Taken together, these tariffs amounted to the highest U.S. tariff rates since the disastrous Smoot-Hawley tariffs of the Great Depression, and would have caused grave damage to the U.S. economy . The main basis for the court’s ruling is that IEEPA does not even mention the word “tariff,” and has never been used to impose them by any previous president during the statute’s nearly 50-year history. The power to “regulate” importation, which IEEPA does grant in some situations, does not include a power to impose taxes. But an additional crucial factor was the sheer scope of the authority claimed by Trump. As Chief Justice John Roberts noted in his opinion for the court, the president claimed virtually unlimited power to “impose tariffs on imports from any country, of any product, at any rate, for any amount of time.” The framers of the Constitution wanted to ensure the president would not be able to repeat the abuses of English kings, who imposed taxes without legislative authorization. Under Trump’s interpretation of the law, the president would have virtually unlimited tariff authority, similar to that of an absolute monarch of the kind King Charles I aspired to be. The court decisively rejected this aspiration to unconstrained presidential power. Roberts’ majority opinion, a concurring opinion by Justice Neil Gorsuch, and one by Justice Elena Kagan (writing for all three liberal justices) all, in different ways , emphasized this aspect of the case. As Gorsuch put it, “Our system of separated powers and checks-and-balances threatens to give way to the continual and permanent accretion of power in the hands of one man. That is no recipe for a republic.” In addition to relying on statutory text, the three conservative justices in the majority also bolstered their holding by citing the “major questions doctrine,” which requires Congress to “speak clearly” when authorizing the executive to make “decisions of vast economic and political significance.” In addition, Justice Gorsuch relied on the nondelegation doctrine, which limits the extent to which Congress can delegate its authority to executive discretion. Together, major questions and nondelegation are valuable tools for constraining presidential power grabs. And these three justices deserve credit for applying them to a Republican president with the same rigor as they previously did with Democratic ones, most notably Joe Biden. But the judiciary’s future ability to constrain dangerous presidential power grabs depends in large part on an issue the court managed to avoid in the IEEPA case: whether and to what extent to defer to presidential assertions that an extraordinary situation exists justifying the invocation of sweeping emergency powers. IEEPA is limited to situations in which there is an “emergency” amounting to an “unusual and extraordinary threat.” Trump’s Liberation Day tariffs were supposedly justified by the threat of trade deficits. But deficits are a common phenomenon , neither unusual nor extraordinary. Nor do they pose any danger to the United States. If trade deficits count as an “unusual and extraordinary threat,” virtually anything does. The fentanyl tariffs also did not address a genuine threat. The flow of fentanyl from Canada to the U.S. is negligible , and the vast bulk of that from Mexico is actually brought in by U.S. citizens coming through legal ports of entry. The court didn’t have to consider whether a genuine “unusual and extraordinary threat” existed in the IEEPA case, because it ruled that IEEPA did not authorize imposition of tariffs in any situation. But, as I explained in an earlier piece for The Dispatch , there are many cases working their way through the court system in which presidential invocations of emergency powers depend on determinations that an emergency of the right type exists. Most notably, Trump has claimed that illegal migration and drug smuggling qualify as an “invasion” that justifies invoking the Alien Enemies Act of 1798, which would grant sweeping power to detain and deport even legal migrants. In the event of “invasion,” the Constitution also grants the federal government the power to detain people without due process. The administration has claimed the president is entitled to broad deference when he asserts an invasion exists. So much so that he could—by the Justice Department’s own admission in an ongoing court case—even invoke the Alien Enemies Act in response to the “British Invasion” of rock stars like the Beatles. The ultimate outcome of the “invasion” litigation remains to be seen. Courts would do well to rule, as some already have, that only a military attack qualifies as an “invasion” and that the executive must prove that one exists before invoking emergency powers, not merely assert it. Trump also demands similar deference for his domestic use of the military . Of course, Republican presidents like Trump are not the only ones who can abuse emergency powers. President Biden sought to do so when he tried to use the COVID emergency as a pretext for a massive student loan forgiveness plan, most of whose beneficiaries were not actually victims of the pandemic (the Supreme Court rightly ruled against the move ). Today, as Justice Gorsuch noted during the tariff case oral arguments, some on the left hope to invoke a “climate emergency,” even though climate change is not a sudden crisis but an ongoing long-term problem. The issue of how much deference to give to presidential invocation of emergencies is also likely to arise again in the context of tariffs. Within hours of the court’s decision, Trump issued an executive order using Section 122 of the Trade Act of 1974 to impose 10 percent global tariffs, before upping the rate to 15 percent the next day. But Section 122 only permits tariffs in response to “fundamental international payments problems” that cause “large and serious United States balance-of-payments deficits” (which are not the same thing as trade deficits), “an imminent or significant depreciation of the dollar,” or to cooperate with other countries in addressing an “international balance-of-payments disequilibrium.” As prominent conservative legal commentator Andrew McCarthy explains in an insightful article for National Review , these preconditions for the use of Section 122 do not exist. There is no “fundamental international payments problem,” and the United States does not have a balance-of-payments deficit. In addition, Section 122 tariffs can only remain in force for up to 150 days unless extended by Congress. But when the Section 122 tariffs are challenged in court (as they likely will be), judges will have to decide whether to defer to Trump on the question of whether the statutory prerequisites are met. And when the 150-day period expires, they may also have to decide whether Trump can extend it simply by claiming a new balance-of-payments problem has arisen. If judges (mistakenly) give him broad deference, Section 122 could become a blank check for presidential tariff-setting that the Supreme Court just denied him in the IEEPA case. More generally, if the courts are not willing to carefully scrutinize executive invocations of sweeping emergency powers, deference to such claims could be a backdoor path to the sort of monarchical authority the court rightly rejected in its tariff decision. Ilya Somin Ilya Somin is a professor of law at George Mason University, the B. Kenneth Simon Chair in Constitutional Studies at the Cato Institute, and author of “Free to Move: Foot Voting, Migration and Political Freedom.” Together with the Liberty Justice Center and others, he was co-counsel in VOS Selections v. Trump, one of the tariff cases decided by the Supreme Court.

title: Trump, Tariffs, and the Dangers of an Unbound Presidency
content: Matthew Mitchell / February 22, 2026 Trump, Tariffs, and the Dangers of an Unbound Presidency The president already found a workaround to impose new tariffs. Will Congress reclaim its power? Law The Supreme Court as seen on February 20, 2026. (Photo by Heather Diehl/Getty Images) The Supreme Court as seen on February 20, 2026. (Photo by Heather Diehl/Getty Images) Audio Audio Turn any article into a podcast. Upgrade now to start listening. Text Size Premium Members can share articles with friends & family to bypass the paywall. Facebook Twitter LinkedIn Threads Email 0 Open and scroll to the comments section The Supreme Court has ruled that President Donald Trump’s “emergency” tariffs are unconstitutional . If we were inclined to keep the republic that Ben Franklin and his colleagues imparted to us, that would be that. Trump would concede that the Constitution means what it says when it grants Congress—and Congress alone—the “power to lay and collect taxes, duties, imposts, and excises.” Congress, meanwhile, would reclaim its power. It could use it in one of two ways: either giving the president the tax on Americans he so craves, or declining to do so. Either way, in the words of Justice Neil Gorsuch, it would “tap the combined wisdom of the people’s elected representatives, not just that of one faction or man.” How quaint. Ideally, everyone would grant that there is some virtue in preserving the basic elements of a republican system: that is, a system in which elected officials have certain limited and enumerated powers granted through the Constitution. And any power not explicitly granted to one branch of the government or another would be reserved for the people or the states, respectively. But, alas, I fear that few in Washington are all that interested in keeping this kind of republic. And so now we wait to see how cute the president tries to get. Getting cute. Two centuries of trade research have shown Adam Smith to have been correct when he declared, “Nothing, however, can be more absurd than this whole doctrine of the balance of trade.” Trump has evidently weighed this research and rejected it. And he’s already shown that he’s not inclined to wait for Congress to delegate tariff powers to him. Though the Supreme Court ruled that he could not use the  International Emergency Economic Powers Act of 1977 (IEEPA) to levy tariffs, there are other statutes that allow the president limited tariff authority. On Friday—mere hours after the court ruled—he signed an executive order imposing 10 percent tariffs on the entire world under Section 122 of the Trade Act of 1974. A few hours later he thought better of it and raised these rates to 15 percent. Section 122 allows him to impose across-the-board tariffs of up to 15 percent to address “balance of payments” issues. Never mind that the balance of payments deficit is currently zero. And never mind that these Section 122 powers were designed “to prevent an imminent and significant depreciation of the dollar in foreign exchange markets.” This is not about to happen. And, ironically, Trump has long sought depreciation of the dollar. These Section 122 tariffs, however, can only last 150 days. After that, he would need to turn to some other authority. Next, he might claim that Section 301 of the Trade Act of 1974 permits him to impose tariffs on any country that has engaged in “unreasonable” or “discriminatory” trade practices. What is an unreasonable or discriminatory trade practice? You might think it is a “practice,” an actual policy adopted by another government. But in Trump’s mind, it is unreasonable any time Americans choose to buy more from the citizens of another country than those citizens buy from us. That, after all, is how he arrived at a 46 percent “reciprocal tariff” on goods bought from Vietnam even though the Vietnamese government imposes only a 9.5 percent duty on goods bought from the US. In any case, a faithful reading of the statute would necessitate a careful and lengthy investigation by the U.S. trade representative before any tariff could be imposed. But Trump could get cute with that too, ordering an expedited and cursory analysis. We’ll have to see how far the courts let him get with that. Next, he might try to use Section 232 of the Trade Expansion Act of 1962 . This allows tariffs on goods that pose a threat to the national security of the United States, but requires a careful Commerce Department investigation into what constitutes a threat. Does Europe’s reluctance to hand over Greenland constitute a threat? Secretary Howard Lutnick’s Commerce Department may well see it that way. Don’t forget that last October, Trump imposed an additional 10 percent tariff on Canadian imports—citing IEEPA authority—because a Canadian premier had aired a commercial featuring Ronald Reagan saying some critical things about tariffs. Speaking of Greenland, Trump never bothered to cite any authority for his threatened tariffs against Denmark, Norway, Sweden, France, Germany, the U.K, the Netherlands, and Finland for their refusal to let him annex an ally’s territory. So, he may simply try to impose tariffs without any authority. Cute. The origins of an unbound presidency. What is wrong with cute? Why should we care? Our duly elected president seems to genuinely believe in tariffs. It may be the one position he has consistently held throughout his decades as a public figure. And voters overwhelmingly chose him in 2024. Don’t they deserve to see their democratically selected policies enacted? For decades now, there have been two unsatisfactory answers to these questions. The first, supplied by progressives operating in the tradition of Woodrow Wilson, is that cute is fine. Wilson thought that “[t]he makers of the Constitution constructed the federal government upon a theory of checks and balances ... but no government can be successfully conducted upon so mechanical a theory.” Rather than think of the government as a machine, he preferred to think of it as a living being , and “[n]o living thing can have its organs offset against each other, as checks, and live.” Wilson was motivated by an outsized view of his own intelligence. Five years before he ascended to the presidency, he wrote , “The President is at liberty, both in law and conscience, to be as big a man as he can. His capacity will set the limit.” If this sounds familiar, recall that Trump recently told the New York Times that his power is limited only by “My own morality. My own mind. It’s the only thing that can stop me.” But long before it captured Trump’s imagination, Wilson’s vision of an unbounded presidency stirred the imagination of the left. In an unprecedented exercise of power, Wilson issued more than 1,800 executive orders, nationalized railroads, and imposed price controls. He also segregated the federal labor force, suppressed free speech, and rounded up thousands of suspected socialists, but those achievements of the progressive era are less celebrated by today’s modern progressives. The unbounded presidency also inspired Franklin D. Roosevelt to close banks, to confiscate gold, and to intern Japanese Americans via executive order. It gave President Barack Obama, frustrated by Congress’ opposition to his agenda, the courage to declare in 2014: “I’ve got a pen, and I’ve got a phone.” And it gave President Joe Biden the notion that he could cancel up to $430 billion in debt owed to the American taxpayers without bothering to seek Congress’ approval. The Constitution, ineptly defended. The great 19 th -century French economist Frédéric Bastiat once warned that “the worst thing that can happen to a good cause is, not to be skillfully attacked, but to be ineptly defended.” Which brings us to the second answer to what’s wrong with cute. Each time a Democrat asserted unbounded presidential or governmental power, there was almost always a Republican there to counter it. Obama’s 2014 pen remarks were especially successful in rousing Republican ire. House Speaker John Boehner declared , “I would remind the president he also has a Constitution and an oath of office that he took” while Sen.Ted Cruz lectured : “‘I have a pen, and I have a phone,’ is not how laws are made under our Constitution. A strong president governs by consensus and persuasion, not with a pen and a phone. Americans deserve a President who will work in good faith with their elected representatives to follow the law of the land and to pass laws that reflect the will of the people.” These are stirring statements. But the Constitution would not be so ineptly defended if Republicans could muster the courage to repeat them today to their own man. To his credit, Cruz has often criticized the wisdom of Trump’s tariffs. But so far, he hasn’t brought himself to challenge the constitutionality of them. His newfound reticence is nothing compared to House Speaker Mike Johnson, however. In January, Johnson declared : “I have no intention of getting in the way of President Turmp and his administration. … He has used the tariff power that he has under Article II very effectively.” Huh? Which Article II power is he talking about? Does he think our keyboards lack a Ctrl-F? A better defense. It is clear now that many Republicans saw constitutional fealty as a nice talking point, a way to skewer Democrats for their unpatriotic rejection of the American founding. But it appears that some Republicans’ own constitutionalism runs about as deep as Trump’s understanding of economics. They favor the Constitution when it thwarts the Democrats. They favor it because it is old and vaguely patriotic. Its antique and loopy cursive make for a beautiful backdrop for a speech. Like the flag itself, it’s the kind of thing you can hug (awkwardly). But it isn’t the kind of thing you think about. But let’s think about it. Few people thought as clearly or as thoroughly about the wisdom of constitutions as the late political economist James Buchanan . When talking about constitutions, the 1986 Nobel laureate liked to invoke Ulysses tying himself to the mast. Ulysses didn’t tie himself to the mast because he wanted to embarrass the Trojans. Nor did he do it because he wanted to inspire his men or remind them of their patriotic forefathers. He did it for far more practical reasons. He knew that he would be tempted by the siren’s song. He knew he would go mad with lust, and he wanted to stop himself. And so it is with political power. Government is not, as former Rep. Barney Frank once naively put it, “the things we choose to do together.” We do all sorts of things together. We start businesses together. We play softball together. We fish, and we pray, and we get drunk at concerts together. But none of those things is government. When we form governments together, we assert the power to legitimately coerce our fellow citizens. No one can make you join the softball league. But government can make you pay your taxes, buy health insurance, or register for the draft. Try selling loose cigarettes on a Staten Island sidewalk and men with guns may stop you. Frank had it exactly backward. Government isn’t what we choose to do together. It’s what we say you don’t have a choice in. Like paying your taxes! Which brings us back to the Supreme Court’s decision. The framers understood that the power to tax is the power to destroy. And so they decided not to give that power to one man. After all, he might wake up one day and get offended by a TV commercial featuring a (more) popular Republican president. Or he might decide that a Swiss politician rubs him the wrong way. Those would be silly, arbitrary, and capricious reasons to coerce money from Americans. So, the framers wisely gave the power to tax to our Congress, imperfect as it may be. They made it difficult for Congress to exercise this power—requiring legislation to pass both houses and constituting each house differently—because they wanted to ensure that this power wasn’t abused. But the system works only if we take the Constitution and our commitment to republican government seriously. The Constitution is not, as progressives in the Wilsonian mold assert, an antiquated document. Nor is it, as some Republicans seem to think, a prop. We may yet keep our republic if we can resist the urge to get cute. Matthew Mitchell Matthew D. Mitchell is a senior fellow with the Fraser Institute, and an affiliated senior scholar with the Mercatus Center at George Mason University.

title: The Monthly Mailbag With Ross Anderson
content: Ross Anderson / February 22, 2026 The Monthly Mailbag With Ross Anderson Our TMD editor answers your questions. General Photo via Ross Anderson. Photo via Ross Anderson. Audio Audio Turn any article into a podcast. Upgrade now to start listening. Text Size Premium Members can share articles with friends & family to bypass the paywall. Facebook Twitter LinkedIn Threads Email 0 Open and scroll to the comments section At the beginning of every month, a different Dispatch staffer fields questions from members and compiles his or her answers in a mailbag a few weeks later. This month, it was Morning Dispatch editor Ross Anderson’s turn. To ensure you’re able to submit questions for March’s Mailbag , click below to become a full Dispatch member. JOIN TODAY! At the beginning of every month, a different Dispatch staffer fields questions from members and compiles his or her answers in a mailbag a few weeks later. This month, it was Morning Dispatch editor Ross Anderson’s turn. Happy Sunday, and thanks to everyone for your great questions. Without further ado … From Richard Kennedy: What have been the reasons and impetus for having lived in almost every hemisphere in your lifetime? You’ve lived far and wide! I was born in Belfast to Northern Irish parents, and they didn’t want their kids growing up around the Troubles, or anything to do with it. But my mother doesn’t like guns, so America was out of the picture, and my father didn’t want to learn French, so I grew up in Australia. I lived in a small hippie town called Mullumbimby in Northern New South Wales, near Byron Bay, then moved to New Zealand as a teenager, came back to Europe for work and education, and moved to London because I wanted to. And I love it! From JohnM: How did you find this job? Or how did it find you? Have you met the bosses yet? Last year was one of the most tumultuous of my career, and in July, I’d basically settled on leaving journalism. I never planned on becoming a writer, and I stumbled into it from blogging as a hobby. I was proud of my work, and passionate about it, but I’d become sick of the instability of the industry, and a lot of the people in it. I’d settled on leaving it to work in tech—but left the door open if a job opened up at a very small list of publications that I loved. And then, one morning, my favorite morning newsletter advertised for a new editor; and within two weeks or so, I had signed on the proverbial dotted line to become its new editor . And yes, Steve and I chat fairly regularly about TMD, making sure that we’re always making it better, and I was actually supposed to grab coffee with Jonah last year as he passed through London, but we didn’t quite make it happen. From Denise Cote (and Mccumberrick ): Of all the places you’ve lived, which country is your favorite and why? From DaveW: What are the pluses and minuses of the varied places you’ve lived? I’m going to skip some smaller spots and give a biggest upside and biggest downside for various places I’ve lived : Australia (East Coast): The best parts: the scenery, beach-swimming, and the wildlife. The worst parts: the blistering heat in summer, the terrible housing market, and (in rural Australia) lack of opportunities to advance or get quality education. New Zealand (Auckland and Waiheke): The best parts: Auckland is basically a European city, but with lovely weather and idyllic scenery. The worst parts: obscenely expensive, particularly given the relative lack of employment opportunities. New Zealand also has a bad housing market, albeit not as disastrous as Australia. Ireland (Dublin): The best parts: It’s a really pretty city, with so much history, and some of the best cocktail bars and pubs in the world. Also, the Luas tram system is great. The worst parts: It’s small, with relatively little to do that you couldn’t experience in a long weekend trip, and you pay an extreme premium to live there compared to any other similar city. Scotland (Glasgow): The best parts: The people. Glaswegians have the best banter and conversations, and I miss them terribly. The worst parts: There are rough parts, and it is a small city. Within a few years, I felt like I’d seen every foot of it too many times over, and wanted more. England (London): The best parts: I live slightly out of the buzz of it all, in a pleasant leafy part, but within 45 minutes, I’m in the middle of one of the oldest, most diverse, bustling cities in the world. Every day, there’s something new to try, or somewhere you haven’t visited yet, and that’s just exciting. Also, so many areas feel utterly unlike any other part; it’s hard to believe that Battersea Power Station, Regent’s Park, Canary Wharf, and Soho are all in the same city. Also, I don’t feel like a stranger or foreigner here, in a way that I have everywhere else I’ve lived. The worst parts: The accommodation scarcity means that every apartment has a massive waiting list, and many are in terrible condition despite the capital-city prices. Also, the public transport infrastructure is great but poorly managed, to put it politely. From Sully: What’s the most underrated city for food, style, culture, etc ... based on extensive globetrotting? Find a random town at the top of a mountain in Sicily and order something simple with lots of wine on the side—it is the best food you will ever try. Also, I adore Las Vegas—it is among the greatest cities in the world. Americans don’t appreciate it enough. I wrote a long tribute to it in The Spectator if you’re interested. Style is a little tougher, because the internet has flattened fashion and you can find the same styles and niches everywhere. Parisians still have a casual understanding of good style, and the Japanese also dress well, as they generally have an excellent understanding of cut. For example, their coats stop closer to the ankle than just below the knee, which is the best length for a coat. I hope American and British brands soon realize this. From Florida Kitty: I’m a single, older woman and travel to Scotland and/or Ireland is on my bucket list. Not sure I can afford both, but will gladly appreciate your insight into cities/towns you think would be safe for an older woman traveling alone, full of history and architecture, beautiful scenery for medium hikes (relatively good health/fitness) and/or short day trips from a central location, and of course, local pubs/distilleries. My experience traveling is that, so long as you use common sense, most places are far safer than people assume. But, to answer the specific question at hand: I would default to recommending a Scotland trip! Start in Glasgow, and get the train up to Oban, where you can have the best fish and chips by the waterfront. Once you’re up there, there are so many staggeringly beautiful places to hike in the Highlands. You can also try any number of wonderful whisky distillery tours in Speyside, and travel back to Edinburgh, which is such a charming city, with so much history. Try a St. Mungo beer when you’re in Glasgow, a great peaty whisky when you’re north, and have Irn-Bru and Tunnock’s Teacakes on your travels. The Irish equivalent would be spending a few days in Dublin, checking out all the various historical spots before heading out to walk in beautiful Wicklow—but I think your dollar will stretch further, and give you a more memorable trip, in Scotland. From Ben Connelly: What have you learned about strength training that you wish you knew earlier? Also is this strength training to just stay in shape or is it for a sport (including powerlifting or bodybuilding)? Do you have a favorite lift/exercise and if so why? I’ve learned that being consistent is far more important and far more difficult than anything else. Just turning up every day for your routine sounds so easy, but you really do have to set up your life in such a way to make that possible. You should also always record your sets (it means you don’t have to count reps, and you can review your form better), and that having a great coach is so worth the money if you care about lifting (shoutout to Trevor). They can help you improve issues you have, program your mesocycles to develop your physique best, and just let you know when things are going well, even if you have doubts. I started training for the general health benefits, but now do so for bodybuilding! As for my favorite exercise, the incline dumbbell chest-supported row is just wonderful. But, to give some more exercises, and explanation: My favorite isolation exercises are those that hit my muscles in tough new ways I haven’t tried before. Namely, decline dumbbell flyes , lying bicep curls , dumbbell curl-to-press , and tough lateral raises (using the full vertical arc, then just to horizontal, then partial reps once you can’t do horizontal anymore either). My favorite compound movements are difficult to master and feel powerful to perform: barbell Romanian deadlift, barbell bent over rows, and, best of all, the bench press, which I do with a wide grip and full powerlifter’s back arch . It’s not unusual to love the bench press, but I think people miss how complex and difficult to master it is. From Derek M: What is the tech gadget you can’t live without? The devices I depend upon that most people don’t have are my Oura Ring 4 Ceramic and Logitech MX Master 4 mouse. If you want to track your steps, sleep, and general health patterns, nothing can beat an Oura Ring. And while the MX Master 4 is an expensive mouse, I have about 40 different shortcuts synced to it, which I use constantly throughout the day, and I would be dramatically less productive and less happy using a different mouse. It’s basically an extension of my hand at this point. From Whiskeyman: I’m curious about the tech worth buying versus not. … What is your No. 1 “you must buy this now” and your No. 1 “never buy this”? What tech upgrade will save me enough money that I should care? I think the product matters less than the person who’s buying it. Most people spend too much money to buy capacity they don’t actually value. If your photo gallery is mostly receipts and the occasional family snapshot, you don’t need an iPhone Pro; whereas, if you hike a lot or have long days out, then you should seriously consider phones with huge batteries, like the OnePlus 15 or Honor Power2, rather than just defaulting to a Samsung or iPhone. As a tech enthusiast, I’m happy to pay a premium for something fun —but most new devices aren’t. The iPhone 17 Pro is great, but it’s an iterative upgrade on the 16 Pro, 15 Pro, and 14 Pro. The devices I love are fun, unique ones, which usually sell poorly because they come with big, unappealing compromises. My daily phone is the iPhone Air, and I adore it because it’s so much lighter and thinner than anything else on the market—but it’s expensive, with a small battery and a single rear camera. The Sigma BF is my favorite camera—utterly gorgeous, with a cool, fast interface and incredible photos—but it’s outrageously expensive, and its minimal design means it lacks features you’d normally expect at that price. I love both because the compromises aren’t big deals for my lifestyle, and the benefits are huge. But that isn’t true for most shoppers. From Rob Hayes: Putting aside the idea of “men’s fashion essentials,” what items in your closet do you find yourself reaching for most often and why? I love fashion, and I love sneakers (I have a few hundred pairs), so I actually try to circle through my outfits a lot to force myself to wear more and feel different. But these are some of the items I’ve been wearing most over the past year or so: NN07 Gael Jacket in the black and gray check: beautifully made, extremely comfortable, and has the best pockets of any jacket. MKI Denim Jacket : I love denim jackets, and own far too many, but my favorite is this boxy one from MKI. You can never wear too much denim; I often wear this jacket with a denim shirt underneath, and jeans below. I even own a denim cowboy hat from a Levi’s Pride collection. Nomos Club Campus with the deep pink dial: a perfect little manual watch, from a factory I had the chance to visit. I buy watches to mark special anniversaries, and this marked my first full year in journalism. (Also, watches don’t need to be new or expensive or flashy to be cool; you just have to like them). Knitted beanies from my sibling: Buying beanies is a waste of money when you can make knitwear of higher quality for much less money by knitting them yourself. Or, in my case, by paying my sibling to make them for me. I have a stack of beanies in all sorts of colors and styles and I love them. Photo via Ross Anderson. From Howmanydiscs: How many belts does a man need? One black, one brown, and that’s it? I bought a solid blue belt a few years ago from Orvis and have been surprised by how often I wear it. And yet my black belt from Orvis, with a gold/yellow stitch, is surprisingly difficult to match. Maybe that’s because I struggle with how to match belts. I should know this, but do you match them to one’s socks? Shoes? Shirt/pants? I’m 55 years old and really need to figure this out! For putting together a great outfit, you generally want to set a base dark tone, which you build up from. That is usually either black or brown (or navy), and it can be set with a signature item—such as a jacket or coat—or with your shoes and belt. Once you have a base tone picked out and set, you can build a look from there; neutrals generally go well with black, colder tones fit navy, and warmer, creamier colors sit well with brown. The important part here is that this base tone is cohesive—you don’t want to wear a black jacket, with a blue belt, and brown shoes. If you want simple starting part, it’s hard to go wrong with: Black belt + black shoes + silver hardware + white shirt Brown belt + brown shoes + gold hardware + cream shirt You don’t need both gold and silver hardware options—most of my stuff is silver, as the gray suits my skin tone better—but if you’re just looking to buy belts, a plain black leather belt and a plain brown leather belt are usually enough for a great wardrobe. But once you understand the principles, go wild! Your blue belt probably sits great with the mid-tones of your outfits, and you set the dark tones with other elements of your look. Fantastic! You can even put black and brown together. I usually wear my dark brown leather jacket with black trousers, black boots, and a white t-shirt. From Richard Kennedy: I really enjoy distilled spirits for the particular spirit’s sake. ... What is the advantage of mixing/diluting these spirits with other stuff for cocktails, particularly the better brands of these spirits? I don’t mean an insult here. I love spirits too! For what it’s worth, Yellow Spot is probably my favorite Irish whiskey—though Method & Madness is very nice too—and Bruichladdich is my favorite Scotch. The answer is that they’re two different disciplines. Making cocktails is like cooking a dish, where you combine ingredients and techniques to get textures, flavors, colors, and experiences that you can’t with a single element. Meanwhile, sipping a great spirit is like trying a great black coffee, appreciating the subtleties of a pure thing. That also means that you shouldn’t use extremely refined spirits in cocktails. You want to use good spirits (I would rather use Chopin or Belvedere instead of Absolut or Smirnoff), but there’s a certain threshold where the nuances of quality spirits get washed out by other ingredients. Just as you wouldn’t make a caramel frappuccino with geisha beans, I would never make a margarita with Clase Azul. From Phillyex1: Favorite cocktail to make and also favorite cocktail to drink—with recipes, please. From SanM: What’s your favorite cocktail to drink, and what was (is) your favorite to make? Or are they the same? Also, not a question but I’m sure you have tons of stories from your bartending days, please feel free to share one. I think my favorites to make are cocktails that people usually have in a cheap, bad way, but done right. Long Island Iced Tea is a wonderful drink when made well, as are margaritas. Also, my chili-and-dark-chocolate margarita is phenomenal. I also really enjoy making espresso martinis, always with freshly brewed espresso, Mr. Black cold brew coffee liqueur, and a nice vodka. I don’t drink much anymore—for sleep and dieting, I mostly drink non-alcoholic Guinness and Lucky Saint —so when I do, I like to have something creative or novel, ordering whatever the cocktail special is, or asking the bartender to make something they like. Also, the strangest drink order I ever received was for a “non-alcoholic decaf Irish Coffee with oatmilk instead of cream.” The customer ordered it with a straight face, and it took me a solid 10 seconds to wrap my head around it. From Launerjennifer: I’d love to know about Teddy! Photo via Ross Anderson. Here is young Teddles, he’s a 2-year-old black mixed breed, and he’s the most lovely, handsome, wonderful cat. He’s not a lap cat, but he’s super affectionate, purring a lot, sitting on or beside my keyboard while I’m editing TMD , and generally bringing me an endless amount of joy. I’ve always been a dog person, but I adore my fluffy feline son. Pet’s Likes: Food; watching films, TV, and my video games; chirping at the local birds; flooping onto my keyboard while I’m trying to edit TMD in order to get cuddles. He also likes walking along the edge of the bath, for some reason. Pet’s Dislikes : Loud drumming outdoors. Being fed even slightly late, or just not early. Thanks for reading this month’s Mailbag ! Keep an eye out for next month’s introductory post, where you’ll be able to ask questions of … visuals editor Noah Hickey . Thanks for reading this month’s Mailbag ! To ensure you’re able to ask questions of visuals editor Noah Hickey next month, become a member today. Ross Anderson Ross Anderson is the Editor of The Morning Dispatch, based in London. Prior to joining the company in 2025, he was an editor at The Spectator, columnist at The New York Sun, and a Tablet fellow. When Ross isn’t working on TMD, he’s probably trying out new tech, lifting weights, or hanging out with his cat, Teddy.

title: Lent Reminds Us That a Penitent Imagination Can Counter Evil
content: Dispatch Faith Lent Reminds Us That a Penitent Imagination Can Counter Evil What’s happening right now is unimaginable, and that’s a problem. Michael Reneau & Hannah Anderson / February 22, 2026 Audio Audio Turn any article into a podcast. Upgrade now to start listening. Text Size Premium Members can share articles with friends & family to bypass the paywall. Facebook Twitter LinkedIn Threads Email 0 Open and scroll to the comments section You’re reading Dispatch Faith , our weekly newsletter exploring the biggest stories in religion and faith. To unlock all of our stories, podcasts, and community benefits—as well as our newest feature, Dispatch Voiced , which allows you to listen to our written stories in your own podcast feed— join The Dispatch as a paying member . We’re hitting the road and heading to Dallas, Texas, for Dispatch Energy: The Current State , a symposium focused on the future of energy innovation. You can catch Jonah Goldberg, Steve Hayes, Kevin D. Williamson, and more of your favorite Dispatch authors as we bring our Dispatch Energy newsletter to life. Tickets are available here —but hurry, they’re almost sold out. Hi and happy Sunday. It’s become commonplace—at least for me—to question how Americans of different political, ideological, or religious points of view seem to interpret the same basic sets of facts so wildly differently from one another. One of my children recently told me about a classmate who said January 6 was both peaceful and good for the country. Competing narratives—call it “spin”—will always be a facet of free societies. But how did we come to a moment in which facts themselves seem to be as up for debate as what those facts mean? In this week’s Dispatch Faith essay, Dispatch Contributing Writer Hannah Anderson contends that what we suffer from is a failure of imagination. Though that phrase often connotes a failure to see the world better than its current state, Anderson points out that Lent might teach us that we’re fighting over facts because we’re failing to view certain situations as being dire as they really are. A Failure of Imagination Illustration by Noah Hickey/The Dispatch (Photos via Unsplash). By HANNAH ANDERSON These days, reacting to the events around us is like a continual Rorschach test. Someone posts a video on social media, and one person will see a virtuous display of patriotism while another will see the fall of democracy. I’ve always understood these differences as political tribalism and garden-variety confirmation bias but lately, I’m beginning to wonder whether they’re something more. I wonder if we’re actually facing a failure of imagination. When I use the language of imagination, I don’t mean a flight of fancy or escape from reality. I’m thinking of our ability to conceive of a reality beyond the one being currently delivered to us. It’s the distinction that 19 th -century author (and scientist) George MacDonald articulated when considering how a person could discover something new, how a person could “be carried beyond himself and the regions of his knowledge.” The answer for MacDonald was that things “must be foreseen ere they can be realized—apprehended ere they be comprehended.” Stories We Think You’ll Like Why New Atheism Crumbled Nick Pompella / February 16, 2026 And will the same thing happen to today’s ‘religious revival’? On ‘White Culture’ Jonah Goldberg / February 18, 2026 The latest poisonous example of horseshoe theory. The Lives That Bought the West Jonny Gartner / February 18, 2026 We cannot forget the sacrifices that gave the rules-based order its moral purpose. In 17 th -century Florence, as Europe sat at a crossroads of profound societal, theological, and even cosmological change, Galileo Galilei and other astronomers turned their telescopes to the moon. But Galileo had an advantage on them. He had been trained in perspective drawing so when he saw shadows on the moon, he saw what others couldn’t: mountains. The telescope was not yet powerful enough to provide unassailable visual proof but his mind’s eye could conceive of their possibility —and from there, he could work to prove their existence. Kerry Magruder , curator and chair of the History of Science Collections at the University of Oklahoma, calls this approach “imaginative realism.” He likens it to how “a man crossing a swollen river relies both on his feet and upon his staff as he extends it out to feel for the next stepping stone.” Rather than a reductionism that is satisfied with simply collecting, curating, and debating facts, imaginative realism calls reason and imagination to partner together to reveal the true nature of reality. Our ability to engage the current moment depends in large part on employing a similar imaginative realism. Not only do we select and curate the data points that serve our personal biases, we no longer even agree on what constitutes a fact. In such a post-factual culture, the question shifts away from what facts we can comprehend to what we can apprehend—what we can imagine to be possible. Right now, we’re forced to consider: Is it possible that the allegations of the Epstein files  actually are  worthy of investigation and prosecution ? Is it possible that married women’s ability to vote could actually be threatened ? Is it possible that history did warn us and that we are repeating its inhumanity by locking our neighbors in camps ? Is it possible that the Christian doctrine of human depravity is true? Those who have experienced such evil firsthand would be quick to say “yes” because they have had their imaginations fundamentally altered by it. They know in a way that the rest of us don’t. So when they warn us about conditions in detention centers or the reality of childhood sexual abuse , they are speaking to our imagination, not just our reason. In this way, “believing survivors” does not mean accepting everything as uncontested fact, but it does mean opening ourselves to the reality that their witness is true. We must take their claims seriously enough to give them a hearing through formal channels of justice, honestly investigate them, and bring charges against the accused should the evidence warrant—no matter who it might implicate. But such warnings are so chilling—so grief-inducing—that often we shut down in the face of them. We struggle to wrap our mind around that kind of evil, so we often just don’t. During COVID, psychologists and scientists warned that as the death toll rose, we would actually become detached from it because our minds could not comprehend the reality of such large, abstract numbers . We may have a vague, impending sense of 1 million deaths, but we’re more emotionally and psychologically affected by 12 discrete deaths that we can attach to particular names and stories. We live in a similar moment politically. In the realities that many people inhabit, it is unimaginable that the United States might already be functioning as a totalitarian state. It is unimaginable that underage girls were abused and trafficked through an elite, global syndicate—and that the man occupying the White House was in the thick of it. It is unimaginable that checks and balances have collapsed so far that Congress would be unlikely to consider impeachment, his involvement. But to riff off Flannery O’Connor, “ The truth does not change according to our ability to imagine it .” On Wednesday the Christian season of Lent began. These six weeks before Easter call the faithful to humility and repentance, “to remember that we are but dust.” And yet, Lenten remembrance is not simply a factual accounting of all the wrongs that we have done; it is also a call to imagine the ways we could have erred without knowing it—that we sin, as the General Confession of the Book of Common Prayer originally put  it, both “by what we have done and by what we have left undone.” This simple act of penitent imagination, of naming possibility, can break the grip of evil because it undermines its ability to hide in plain sight. Political theorist Hannah Arendt famously spoke of the “ banality of evil ,” But as Arendt understands it, the danger of evil is not simply that it is mundane but that it is: ‘thought-defying’… because thought tries to reach some depth, to go to the roots, and the moment it concerns itself with evil, it is frustrated because there is nothing. That is its ‘banality.’ Only the good has depth that can be radical. Put more simply, evil is both more pervasive and more boring than we imagine. And it feeds on our obliviousness. Imagination, then, may be one of the greatest forms of dissent in that it helps us see the possibilities of evil and unmask them. Imagination also allows us to enter into the plight of our neighbors who suffer under its brutality. And perhaps more than anything, imagination lets us conceive of a reality beyond the one we currently inhabit, showing us that things don’t have to be the way they are. If the world order as we know it is collapsing , as some say, we must find a way to imagine that possibility. But we must also find a way to imagine the radical possibilities of goodness and the world that we want to make on the other side. This will require us to exercise the vision of those who “ have a dream .” It will also require that we pray that God’s kingdom come and confess all the ways we resist earth being made as heaven. Two decades ago it seemed that organized religion was on the decline, and leading the charge against it were the Four Horsemen of New Atheism: Christopher Hitchens, Richard Dawkins, Sam Harris, and Daniel Dennett. But now—even as we know gauging what people believe is usually more nuanced than simple survey questions—we remember New Atheism is a cultural flash in the pan. Why? In this week’s Monday Essay , Nick Pompella talked to thinkers like Zachary Davis of the nonprofit Faith Matters (and a former New Atheist) to examine why New Atheism faded so quickly, and whether today’s religious believers should heed some lessons therein. For my part, my return to religion is totally mundane. At some point in college, I realized that one could construct an entirely rational view of the universe that still had God at the center; for now, it is the only way to answer the question “Why is there something rather than nothing?” that doesn’t resort to pseudoscientific babble like the multiverse theory . The Christian interpretation also didn’t summon up the immense anger that New Atheism seemed to use as its main fuel. Why did religion make Christopher Hitchens so heated? These supposed titans of capital-L Logic got moody, snide, and annoyed whenever they made their arguments about religion. Why do I feel like the level-headed one now, when I’m on the side of the supposed “ sky daddy ” worshippers? The closest thing to a resolution I have come to is that, basically, Davis is right. New Atheism was a kind of emotionally motivated rage against the idea of living in a world where one’s behavior was not fully liberated from all that came before us. If we’re enlightened denizens of the 21st century, it should be up to us to decide everything about our lives. Inheriting the family religion and all of its attendant communal duties cuts against all of that. There was a desire in New Atheism to insist upon the blank slate model of human behavior—that we get to make every single choice on our own from the word “go.” A lot of New Atheism began from this place of indignation, and then engaged in mental gymnastics to rationalize that feeling. The more conciliatory tone of the surviving crop of atheist influencers, and their openness to spirituality, seems to indicate that this was a losing strategy in the long term. I for one certainly grew out of it; “when I became a man, I put away childish things,” and all that. Kirk is doubtful that another push by secular-minded people will take the shape or size of New Atheism again. “It’s possible,” he told me. “But let’s remember that New Atheism was likely a response to 9/11.” In fact, Sam Harris’ first book, The End of Faith , was written explicitly because of 9/11. This was a no-holds-barred critique of all religious belief, which Harris said was originally “a long essay … produced in those first weeks of collective grief and stupefaction” following September 11, 2001.
